DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Specimen Paraffin Section Preparation Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a description for the process used to preserve tissue collected from a tumor composed of cancer cells by embedding it in a waxy solid that is sliced very thinly for examination under a microscope.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Specimen Paraffin Section Preparation
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the process of preserving tissue collected from a tumor composed of cancerous cells by embedding it in a waxy alkane solid that is sliced very thinly for examination under a microscope.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Paraffin is a common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily. (from Wikipedia):A very thin slice (of tissue or mineral or other substance) for examination under a microscope.:The act or process of making something ready; also a medication made ready for administration; also an anatomic or pathologic specimen made ready and preserved for study.

Concepts.definition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
A very thin slice (of tissue or mineral or other substance) for examination under a microscope.
The act or process of making something ready.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.
